questions.question: A 65 y/o woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with fever and malaise. Blood cultures reveal a typical organism causing infective endocarditis. Echocardiography shows a 2 cm vegetation on the mitral valve. Based on the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which of the following is considered a typical organism strongly associated with infective endocarditis (IE)?
questions.explanation: Typical Non-Typical For General cases: Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus lugdunensis Enterococcus faecalis (Option A) All streptococci (except Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus pyogenes) Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, Gemella species HACEK group (e.g., Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) For cases involving intracardiac prosthetic material , additional typical organisms include: Coagulase-negative staphylococci Corynebacterium striatum, Corynebacterium jeikeium Serratia marcescens, Cutibacterium acnes Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C ruled out) Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium chimaera) Candida species Organisms classified as non-typical are less frequently associated with IE and require three or more positive blood cultures for diagnosis. Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B ruled out) Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out) Non-faecalis enterococci Reference: www.iscvid.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/2023-The-2023-Duke-ISCVID-Criteria-for-Infective-Endoc arditis-Fowler-CID-May-4-2023-Final.pdf Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1026 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 529

questions.question: A 78 y/o male, 3 months post-Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR), presents with fever and signs of systemic infection. What is the most common causative organism in TAVR-associated infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation: endocarditis, especially within the first year post-procedure. Causative organisms of Infective endocarditis: Native valve endocarditis : Community-acquired: Streptococcus viridans (Option A ruled out) Hospital-acquired/health care associated: Staphylococcus aureus. (Option C ruled out) Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis (PVE) Causative Organisms Duration Common pathogens Early PVE (Within the First 2 Months Post-Surgery) (Often due to direct intraoperative contamination or hematogenous spread.) Coagulase-negative staphylococci (Staphylococcus epidermidis, often methicillin-susceptible) (most common) Staphylococcus aureus Gram-negative bacilli Candida species (Option D ruled out) Intermediate PVE (2-12 Months Post-Surgery) Coagulase-negative staphylococci (S.epidermidis) Staphylococcus aureus Streptococci Enterococci Late PVE (After 12 Months Post-Surgery) S.viridans (most common) Staphylococcus aureus Coagulase-negative staphylococci Enterococci Causative Organisms and Incidence of Infective Endocarditis (IE) 1. Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)-Associated IE: Causative Organisms : Enterococcus spp. is the primary organism. (Option B) Incidence : IE following TAVR procedures is not uncommon, with the risk related to the procedure itself and the implantation of a prosthetic valve, which can serve as a nidus for infection. 2. Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices (CIEDs)-Associated IE: Causative Organisms : Gram-positive bacteria, particularly Staphylococcus epidermidis (coagulase-negative staphylococci) are the most common pathogens responsible. Staphylococci (especially Staphylococcus aureus ) are also responsible. Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) has been reported in varying degrees of frequency. Incidence : The incidence of IE is higher in devices like Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICDs) and Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT) compared to pacemakers due to the larger device size and more invasive nature of the procedure. 3. Pacemaker-Associated IE: Causative Organisms : Similar to other CIEDs, Staphylococcus epidermidis is the primary causative organism in pacemaker-related IE. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536987/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431075/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK526001/

questions.question: A 72 y/o man presents with fever and night sweats. Blood cultures are repeatedly negative, but PCR testing from a sterile joint aspirate identifies Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiography reveals mitral regurgitation. Based on the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which of the following is a minor criterion for diagnosing infective endocarditis?

options.C: PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen

questions.explanation: tissue is now a minor criterion. The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Minor Criteria Updates Predisposing Conditions Expanded to include transcatheter valve procedures, endovascular leads of cardiac implantable devices, and a history of IE. Vascular Phenomenon Includes splenic and cerebral abscesses. Immunological Phenomena Clarifies immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, with a practical definition involving unexplained acute kidney injury, hematuria, proteinuria, or a renal biopsy showing immune complex disease. Microbiological Evidence PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing of typical pathogens from sterile sites other than cardiac tissue is now a minor criterion. (Option C) Imaging Abnormal metabolic activity detected by [18F]FDG PET/CT within three months of prosthetic valve or device implantation is included. Physical Exam A new regurgitant murmur on auscultation is considered a minor criterion when echocardiography is unavailable. Negative blood cultures (Option A): While negative blood cultures can occur in IE, especially in cases involving fastidious organisms or prior antibiotic use, this is not a minor criterion. Blood culture positivity, when present, is a major criterion, not a minor one. Echocardiogram revealing mitral regurgitation (Option B): While the presence of a regurgitant murmur may suggest valvular dysfunction, it is a major criterion in Modified Duke’s criteria and is not a minor criteria update in the 2023 ISCVID classification. Fever and night sweats (Option D): Fever is a minor criterion for diagnosing IE according to the Modified Duke criteria, as it suggests systemic infection. It is not a newly added criterion. Night sweats may also be symptomatic of IE, but it does not independently qualify as minor diagnostic criteria. Reference: www.researchgate.net/publication/370520403_The_2023_Duke-ISCVID_Criteria_for_Infective_Endoca rditis_Updating_the_Modified_Duke_Criteria

questions.question: A 70 y/o man with a prosthetic aortic valve has a fever, positive blood cultures for Enterococcus faecalis, valve vegetation, and regurgitation on ECHO. Cardiac Computed Tomography shows a valve abscess. Which finding is a new major criterion for infective endocarditis in the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria?

options.A: Cardiac computed tomography (CCT) showing valvular abscess
options.C: Positive blood cultures with Enterococcus faecalis
options.D: Development of a new valve regurgitation

questions.explanation: now considered major criteria according to the updated 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis. The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Major Criteria Updates Microbiological Criteria Expanded "Typical" Pathogens : The list now includes Staphylococcus lugdunensis, Enterococcus faecalis, and other streptococci, excluding S. pneumoniae and S. pyogenes. Additionally, Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, and Gemella species are now recognised as typical IE pathogens. Prosthetic Material-Associated Pathogens : In intracardiac prosthetic devices, certain bacteria like coagulase-negative staphylococci and Corynebacterium species, as well as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, are considered typical. Simplified Blood Culture Protocol : Timing and separate venipuncture rules have been removed, though separate draws are still ideal. Fastidious Pathogens : New criteria account for hard-to-culture organisms like Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella, and Tropheryma whipplei, diagnosed via PCR or specific serology. Imaging Criteria Cardiac CT (CCT): Findings like valvular vegetation, perforation, aneurysm, intracardiac fistula or abscesses on CCT are now considered major criteria. (Option A) [18F]FDG PET/CT : Abnormal metabolic activity on [18F]FDG PET/CT, especially around prosthetic valves or intracardiac devices, is recognised as a major diagnostic criterion. Surgical Evidence Intraoperative Findings : Direct visual evidence of IE during surgery, such as vegetations or abscesses, qualifies as a major criterion in cases without other definitive findings. Echocardiogram revealing vegetation (Option B), Positive blood cultures with Enterococcus faecalis (Option C), and Development of a new valve regurgitation (Option D): All of these conditions are already established under Major criteria of Modified Duke’s Criteria. Reference: www.iscvid.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/2023-The-2023-Duke-ISCVID-Criteria-for-Infective-Endoc arditis-Fowler-CID-May-4-2023-Final.pdf Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1026 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 529

questions.question: A 65 y/o male patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents to the dental clinic for a tooth extraction. He has a prosthetic heart valve placed two years ago and reports a penicillin allergy. He is otherwise healthy. Which of the following prophylactic antibiotic regimens should be administered to this patient before his dental procedure to prevent infective endocarditis?

options.A: Amoxicillin 2g orally 1 hour before the procedure
options.B: Ampicillin 2g IV or IM within 1 hour before the procedure
options.C: Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure
options.D: Cefazolin 1g IV or IM 30 minutes before the procedure

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure Explanation: Clarithromycin is a suitable alternative for patients with penicillin allergies and is indicated for prophylaxis in patients with prosthetic heart valves. High-risk cardiac Lesions for endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures Prophylactic Antibiotic Regimens for endocarditis in adults with high-risk cardiac lesions Prosthetic heart valves or material Left ventricular assist devices or implantable cardiac defibrillator. Prior endocarditis. Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits. Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair. Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to the prosthetic material. Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation. Standard oral regimen (Option A ruled out) Amoxicillin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure Inability to take oral medication (Option B ruled out) Ampicillin: 2g IV or IM within 1hr before procedure Penicillin allergy Clarithromycin or Azithromycin: 500 mg PO 1hr before procedure. Cephalexin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure. Doxycycline: 100 mg oral 1hr before procedure. Penicillin allergy, inability to take oral medication (Option D ruled out) Cefazolin or Ceftriaxone: 1g IV or IM 30 mins before the procedure. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1033, 1034

questions.question: A 55 y/o man with a history of prosthetic valve presents with fever, chills, and fatigue. Blood cultures reveal methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient has a prosthetic valve and shows evidence of vegetation on echocardiography. What is the appropriate antibiotic regimen for managing this patient’s infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vancomycin + Gentamicin + Rifampin Explanation: The patient has MRSA prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE). The appropriate treatment includes Vancomycin + Rifampin (for 6–8 weeks) and Gentamicin (for 2 weeks). Rifampin is crucial for targeting bacteria in biofilms which are formed on prosthetic valve. Treatment of Infective Endocarditis Based on Pathogen and Valve Type Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) NVE : Vancomycin or Daptomycin for 6 weeks. (Option B ruled out) PVE : Vancomycin + Rifampin(both for 6-8 weeks)+ Gentamicin(for 2 weeks) Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) PVE: Nafcillin + Rifampin (both for 6-8 weeks) + Gentamicin(for 2 weeks) (Option C ruled out) Enterococcal Endocarditis Ampicillin + Gentamicin both for 4-6 weeks (Option D ruled out) Streptococcal Endocarditis Ceftriaxone/Penicillin + Gentamicin. Q fever (Coxiella burnetii) Doxycycline + Hydroxychloroquine. Bartonella Endocarditis Doxycycline + Gentamicin. Fungal Endocarditis (Candida species) IV Amphotericin B + Flucytosine. If PVE, early surgery is recommended due to rapid progression. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1029,1030

questions.question: Which of the following is a minor criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria for infective endocarditis?

options.B: Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Presence of a prosthetic valve Explanation: Modified Duke’s Criteria - Minor criteria Predisposing heart condition Any pre-existing valvular or cardiac abnormality, such as valvular disease, congenital heart defects, or prosthetic valves. (Option C) Intravenous drug use Recognised as a significant risk factor for IE. Fever ≥ 38°C Commonly seen in patients with IE. Vascular phenomena Such as embolic events (stroke, septic pulmonary infarcts), mycotic aneurysms, intracranial haemorrhages and Janeway lesions. Immunological phenomena Rheumatoid factor, Osler’s nodes, Roth's spots or glomerulonephritis. Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria Isolation of organisms typical of IE in a single culture or other non-major findings. Suggestive echocardiography Abnormal findings that raise suspicion but do not meet the criteria for a major criterion. (D529) Positive echocardiographic findings of vegetation (Option A), Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism (Option B), Abscess formation on echocardiogram (Option D): All the given conditions form the major criteria for Infective Endocarditis in Modified Duke’s criteria. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1026 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 529

questions.question: A 60 y/o man with a mechanical aortic valve presents with 2 weeks of fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has a history of a dental procedure done 3 weeks back. Blood cultures are negative. FDG-PET/CT shows abnormal uptake around the valve. Which major criterion from the Modified Duke’s Criteria does this patient meet?

options.A: Negative blood culture for a typical organism
options.B: Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT Explanation: The FDG-PET/CT scan revealed abnormal uptake around the prosthetic valve, which is considered a major criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria. FDG-PET/CT is useful in cases involving prosthetic valves where traditional blood cultures might be negative, helping to detect inflammation around the valve, consistent with endocardial involvement. Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria Positive blood cultures Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart. Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least one hour apart. A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800. Evidence of endocardial involvement Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation. Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve. Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology) Negative blood culture for a typical organism (Option A): Negative blood cultures do not satisfy the major criterion in the Modified Duke’s Criteria. The criterion requires positive cultures for typical organisms like Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus viridans, but in this case, cultures are negative. Abscess formation (Option C): While abscess formation can be a major criterion in infective endocarditis, imaging is needed to confirm this. There was no mention of an abscess either on the echocardiogram or the FDG-PET/CT in this case. Recent history of dental procedures (Option D): Although dental procedures can predispose patients to infective endocarditis, it is not a major criterion in the Modified Duke’s Criteria. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1026 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 529

questions.question: A 60- y/o woman with a history of RHD presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent fatigue, fever, and visual disturbances. O/E multiple linear red to brownish streaks under her fingernails and a pale-centred retinal haemorrhage were observed. Blood cultures reveal the presence of Staphylococcus aureus . Which peripheral lesions associated with the patient’s condition are described by the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Roth spots and splinter hemorrhages Explanation: The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of infective endocarditis in this patient, supported by her h/o RHD , presenting symptoms of persistent fatigue and fever , and the identification of Staphylococcus aureus in blood cultures , indicating an active infection involving the heart valves. The peripheral manifestations of her condition are reflected in the presence of Roth spots, which are pale-centred retinal haemorrhages seen during a fundoscopic examination, and splinter haemorrhages , which are linear red to brown streaks under her fingernails. Cardiac Manifestations Heart murmurs : Present in 80-85% of cases, usually indicating predisposing cardiac pathology; new or worsened regurgitant murmurs occur in 20-50% of patients. Congestive heart failure (CHF) : Occurs in 30-40% due to valve dysfunction or intracardiac fistulae. Paravalvular abscesses : Develop when leaflet infection extends into adjacent tissue, causing intracardiac fistulae and new murmurs. Heart block : Aortic paravalvular infections can burrow into the upper ventricular septum, leading to heart block. Coronary artery emboli : Occur in 2% of patients, potentially causing myocardial infarction. Non-Cardiac Manifestations: Peripheral manifestations : Janeway lesions: Painless, erythematous macules on palms and soles. Related to septic microembolization, (Option A ruled out) Osler’s nodes: Small painful pea-shaped nodules located at the tips of fingers and toes (Immune complex mediated). (Option A ruled out) Subungual haemorrhages/Splinter haemorrhages: More common in acute S. aureus IE. Haemorrhages below nails- multiple linear lesions, initially red then turning brown or black. Splinter hemorrhages" data-author="" Splarka - Own work"" data-hash="8844" data-license="OPEN ACESS" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Splinter_hemorrhage#/media/File:Splinter_hemorrhage.jpg" data-tags="April2025" height="330" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4wwzy51cNNejMMqhXwRU1744308670.png" width="284" /> Roth spots: Pale-centred retinal haemorrhages that are seen in the fundus examination Arterial emboli : Occur in up to 50% of patients, often preceding IE diagnosis, causing organ dysfunction (e.g., stroke, kidney, spleen, or limb ischemia). Neurologic complications : Strokes complicate 15-35% of cases; also include encephalopathy, seizures, meningitis, intracranial haemorrhage, mycotic aneurysms, and brain abscesses. Renal complications : Hypocomplementemic glomerulonephritis due to immune complex deposition, often improving with antimicrobial therapy; renal infarcts may cause flank pain and hematuria. Ulcerative lesions and petechiae (Option C) : Ulcerative lesions are not typical of infective endocarditis, and petechiae were not mentioned in the patient’s

questions.question: In the context of infective endocarditis, what role do MSCRAMMs play in the disease process? endothelium.

options.A: They enhance the immune response against pathogens during bacteremia.
options.B: They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured
options.C: They are responsible for the formation of emboli that lead to tissue infarction.
options.D: They promote the breakdown of vegetation formed in the heart.

questions.explanation: (NBTE) or injured endothelium. Correct Answer: B) They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium. Explanation: MSCRAMMs (microbial surface components recognizing adhesin matrix molecules) are key adhesion factors that enable bacteria to attach to NBTE or damaged endothelium, crucial for the establishment of infective endocarditis. Pathophysiology Endothelial injury : Damage from high-velocity blood jets or cardiac lesions (e.g., mitral regurgitation, aortic stenosis) leads to platelet-fibrin thrombus formation, creating a nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). Thrombus as a bacterial site : The thrombus becomes a site for bacterial attachment during transient bacteremia. Hypercoagulable states : Conditions like malignancy (marantic endocarditis), systemic lupus erythematosus, and antiphospholipid syndrome cause bland vegetation. Bacterial entry : Pathogens enter the bloodstream from colonized surfaces or infection sites. Staphylococcus aureus can adhere to intact endothelial cells through von Willebrand factor, which is induced by local inflammation . This facilitates platelet and bacterial adherence. Adhesion to NBTE: MSCRAMMs are molecules, present on pathogens, that allow bacteria to adhere to damaged endothelium or sites of NBTE . Common components include: Fibronectin-binding proteins (in gram-positive bacteria ) Clumping factor (on S. aureus ) etc. S. aureus can invade intact endothelium using fibronectin-binding proteins , allowing infection to develop even in previously healthy heart valves. Once bacteria adhere, they form microcolonies that resist serum bactericidal activity and the microbicidal peptides released by platelets. Vegetation formation : Fibrin, platelets, and microorganisms combine into infected vegetations. Clinical symptoms : Arise from intracardiac damage, embolization, remote tissue infection or infarction, and immune-mediated injury. Complications of Embolization in Infective Endocarditis : Tissue Infarction : Embolized vegetation fragments can obstruct blood flow, causing infarctions in organs like the brain, kidneys, spleen, and extremities. Left-sided infective endocarditis typically affects the brain and spleen, while right-sided IE often leads to pulmonary embolism. Hematogenous Infection : Vegetation fragments can spread bacteria to distant organs, causing secondary infections like brain abscesses or lung infections. Immune-Mediated Damage : Circulating immune complexes may deposit in tissues, resulting in immune-related injury. They enhance the immune response against pathogens during bacteremia (Option A) : MSCRAMMs do not enhance the immune response; instead, they help bacteria adhere to surfaces, which can evade immune detection. They are responsible for the formation of emboli that lead to tissue infarction (Option C : While bacterial fragments can lead to emboli, MSCRAMMs are not responsible for their formation; they primarily assist in bacterial adherence. They promote the breakdown of vegetation formed in the heart (Option D) : MSCRAMMs do not promote the breakdown of vegetation; they play a role in bacterial adherence and colonization rather than in vegetation degradation.

questions.question: A 65 y/o male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with fever, malaise, and a new heart murmur. He recently underwent a urinary catheterisation for urinary retention. Blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci. What is the most likely causative organism of his infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Enterococcus faecalis Explanation: Enterococcus faecalis is a gram-positive cocci and is frequently linked to infective endocarditis following genitourinary procedures, such as catheterization. Portals of entry Oral cavity: The entry point for viridans streptococci. Skin: Common entry point for staphylococci and S.epidermidis. Upper respiratory tract: Source for HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, Kingella). (Option D ruled out) Gastrointestinal tract: Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly S. bovis) is associated with colonic polyps and tumours. (Option B ruled out) Genitourinary tract and GI tract procedures ( catheterization, colonoscopy): Source for enterococci. Nosocomial (hospital-acquired) sources: S. aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), and enterococci are often linked to healthcare-associated infective endocarditis. (Option A ruled out) Prosthetic valve infections (PVE): Intraoperative contamination or postoperative infection, especially with S. aureus, CoNS, and gram-negative bacilli. Intravenous drug use: Primary portal for S. aureus infections, especially in tricuspid valve involvement. (Option A ruled out) Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1023

questions.question: A 68 y/o male with a prosthetic valve presents with fever, night sweats, and fatigue 6 months post-surgery. Blood cultures are negative, and he was exposed to a contaminated heater-cooler device during valve replacement. Which organism is most likely responsible for his prosthetic valve endocarditis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Mycobacterium chimaera Explanation: Mycobacterium chimaera has been linked to global outbreaks of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) due to contamination from heater-cooler machines used during cardiopulmonary bypass. Culture-Negative Infective Endocarditis (IE): Common Cause : One-third to one-half of culture-negative cases are due to prior antibiotic exposure. Fastidious Organisms : Streptococci , Granulicatella , and Abiotrophia species. HACEK organisms-Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella Coxiella burnetii , and Bartonella species. Special Cases : Tropheryma whipplei. : Associated with Whipple's disease (GI symptoms, arthritis, carditis) Causes an indolent, afebrile, culture-negative form of IE. C. burnetii : Frequently infects prosthetic valves. Corynebacterium species and Propionibacterium acnes : Linked to intracardiac devices, slow-growing in cultures. Mycobacterium chimaera : Difficult to grow, associated with global PVE outbreaks due to heater-cooler machine contamination. Mimics of IE : Atrial myxoma, marantic endocarditis, and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome may present similarly to culture-negative IE. SHOTGUN Metagenomics Shotgun metagenomic sequencing captures all genes from every organism in a complex sample. It enables the evaluation of microbial diversity and the detection of microbial abundance across different environments. This method allows the study of microorganisms that cannot be cultured using traditional techniques. Utilizes next-generation sequencing (NGS) for detailed and comprehensive microbial analysis. Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): A common cause of early prosthetic valve infections but not linked to heater-cooler contamination. Streptococcus viridans (Option C): Typically causes subacute native valve endocarditis and late PVE, not associated with contaminated devices. Coxiella burnetii (Option D): Causes chronic Q fever endocarditis, often linked to animal exposure, not heater-cooler devices. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1023,1024 www.illumina.com/areas-of-in terest/microbiology/microbial-sequencing-methods/shotgun-metagenomic-sequencing.html#:~:text=What%20is%20 shotgun%20metagenomic%20sequencing,in%20a%20given%20complex%20sample.&text=This%20next%2Dgener ation%20sequencing%20(NGS,difficult%20or%20impossible%20to%20analyze.

questions.question: A 30 y/o female with a history of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) presents with fever, fatigue, and a new-onset systolic murmur. Her recent echocardiogram shows vegetation along the inner lining of her aorta. She is an intravenous drug user and has been experiencing unexplained weight loss over the past month. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on her symptoms and history?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Infective endarteritis Explanation: The patient’s history of PDA, intravenous drug use, and new onset systolic murmur which indicates altered blood flow, possibly due to the PDA or from vegetation affecting the blood flow through the aorta or associated vessels strongly suggests infective endarteritis. Infective endarteritis Infective endarteritis is an infection of the inner layer of arteries, often affecting shunts (arteriovenous, arterio-arterial like PDA) or coarctation of the aorta. It was once the leading cause of death in patients with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Now rare due to the routine use of antibiotics and surgical PDA closure, especially in asymptomatic patients or those with silent PDAs. Associated with PDA, the most frequent complications are left heart failure and infective endarteritis. Pathogenesis : Caused by turbulence in blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery and subsequent endothelial injury, leading to bacterial seeding and vegetation formation. Incidence : Predisposing factors include intravenous drug use, sepsis, congenital heart disease, and the presence of indwelling catheters. Diagnosis : Common bacteria : Staphylococcus and Streptococcus viridans TEE (Transesophageal echocardiography) is more sensitive than TTE (Transthoracic echocardiography) for visualising vegetation in adults. Treatment : IV bactericidal antibiotics for 2-6 weeks. Surgery is necessary for patients with PDA and infective endarteritis due to the risk of severe complications (e.g., heart failure, septic emboli, arrhythmias, strokes or mycotic aneurysms). Acute bacterial endocarditis (Option A) typically presents with rapid-onset symptoms and is more commonly associated with high-virulence organisms. The gradual onset of this patient's symptoms, history of PDA, and vegetation along the aorta point more towards infective endarteritis. Subacute bacterial endocarditis (Option B): The patient's history of PDA and the specific mention of vegetation along the aorta point more towards infective endarteritis rather than typical subacute endocarditis. Myocardial infarction (Option D): This is unlikely as the symptoms and findings are consistent with an infectious process rather than ischemic heart disease. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1022 www.illumina.com/areas-of-interest /microbiology/microbial-sequencing-methods/shotgun-metagenomic-sequencing.html#:~:text=What%20is%20shotg un%20metagenomic%20sequencing,in%20a%20given%20complex%20sample.&text=This%20next%2Dgeneration %20sequencing%20(NGS,difficult%20or%20impossible%20to%20analyze. synapse.koreamed.org/articles/1018106

questions.question: A 72 y/o female with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with a low-grade fever, night sweats, and fatigue persisting for over a month. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and petechiae on her extremities. Blood cultures are sent. What is the leading organism associated with this patient's probable condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus viridans. Explanation: The patient's symptoms have persisted for over a month, aligning with the gradual onset characteristic of subacute bacterial endocarditis. Additionally, her history of mitral valve prolapse suggests a predisposing condition for the development of endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans is the most common organism associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis, particularly in individuals with underlying heart conditions. Acute Bacterial Endocarditis Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (SBE) Aggressive course compared to subacute endocarditis. Causative organisms : S. aureus (Most common cause) (including MRSA), S. pneumoniae, L. monocytogenes, Haemophilus species, streptococci (groups A, B, G). Risk factors : Comorbid conditions like malignancy, diabetes mellitus, IV drug use, or alcoholism. Presentation : Fever, fatigue, and malaise within <2 weeks of infection. Changing heart murmur, potential congestive heart failure. Possible signs: Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic macules on palms/soles), petechiae, Roth’s spots, splinter haemorrhages, splenomegaly (rare). Slow progression compared to Acute endocarditis Causative organism: Streptococcus viridans (Most common cause) Presentation : Gradual onset over weeks to months (>2 weeks) but can be life-threatening if untreated. Symptoms: unexplained fever, chills, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, joint/muscle aches, chest/back pain, and skin rashes. Risk Factors : Periodontal disease, IV drug use, prolonged IV medication. Congenital heart defects, prior endocarditis, valve surgery, or pacemaker implants. More common in men, especially over age 60. Treatment : High-dose IV antibiotics for 2-6 weeks. Surgery may be needed for abscess drainage or valve repair/replacement. Staphylococcus aureus (Option A) is more commonly associated with acute bacterial endocarditis. Enterococcus faecalis (Option C) and HACEK organisms (Option D) are less frequent causes of subacute cases than Streptococcus viridans. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470547/

questions.question: Which of the following lists the valves in order of frequency of involvement in infective endocarditis, from most to least commonly affected?

options.A: Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve
options.B: Aortic valve > Mitral valve > Pulmonic valve > Tricuspid valve
options.C: Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Pulmonic valve
options.D: Pulmonic valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve Explanation: This is the correct order, as the mitral valve is the most frequently involved in infective endocarditis, followed by the aortic valve, then the tricuspid valve and the pulmonic valve are rarely involved. Incidence of Infective Endocarditis Low-Risk Condition : Atrial septal defect (ASD) has a negligible risk for infective endocarditis (IE) due to the slow velocity of shunt flow, making it less likely for bacteria to colonize. Valve Susceptibility : The valves in the mitral valve position are generally more susceptible to infection than those in the aortic area. Predisposing Condition : Among young adults, mitral valve prolapse is the most common condition that predisposes to infective endocarditis. Order of Valve Involvement : Infective endocarditis occurs most frequently on the: Mitral valve Aortic valve Combined mitral and aortic valves Tricuspid valve Pulmonic valve (rarely involved) Reference: Infective endocarditis - Cardiology Explained - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding right-sided infective endocarditis (IE)? infective endocarditis. endocarditis

options.A: Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided
options.B: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in right-sided infective endocarditis
options.C: Injecting particles are more likely to reach the right-sided valves compared to the left-sided valves
options.D: Right-sided infective endocarditis has a better long-term prognosis compared to left-sided infective

questions.explanation: than left-sided infective endocarditis. Correct answer: A) Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided infective endocarditis. Explanation: Enterococci are more common in left-sided infective endocarditis than in right-sided IE. Intravenous Drug Use (IDU) and Infective Endocarditis (IE) IDU is strongly associated with infective endocarditis (IE) due to non-sterile injection techniques, allowing skin bacteria and other particles to enter the bloodstream, causing endothelial damage and infection, especially at heart valves. More commonly affects right side of the heart. Right-Sided IDU-Associated IE Left-Sided IDU-Associated IE Valve Involvement : Predominantly affects the tricuspid valve. Causative Pathogen : Staphylococcus aureus (Especially MRSA) is responsible for 85% of cases , primarily due to poor injection hygiene. (Option B ruled out) Pathophysiology : Injected particles damage right-sided valves. Bacteremia from skin bacteria (like S. aureus ) easily colonizes these valves. Surgical Intervention : Surgery is rare and tricuspid valve insufficiency is generally well tolerated. Prognosis : Right-sided IE has a better long-term prognosis. (Option D ruled out) Valve Involvement : Affects the aortic or mitral valves, occurring in about 20-30% of IDU-related IE cases. Causative Pathogen : S. aureus causes 46% of cases, but alpha-hemolytic streptococci and enterococci are more common than in right-sided IE. (Option A) Pathophysiology : Left-sided IE often occurs in individuals with underlying valve disease or degenerative changes, which are more common in older patients. Injected particles are less likely to reach the left-sided valves because they often get trapped in the lungs. (Option C ruled out) Surgical Intervention : Surgery is much more common due to the more severe nature of left-sided lesions (e.g., abscess formation, severe heart failure). Prognosis : Left-sided IE has a worse prognosis Reference: Left vs right IDU IE Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1023,1024

questions.question: A 72 y/o woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath after a stressful argument. She is post-menopausal with no history of heart disease. O/E, she is slightly tachycardic with normal blood pressure. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular ballooning during systole, and cardiac enzymes are minimally elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ventricular dysfunction often triggered by emotional or physical stress . The patient’s recent stressful event, post-menopausal status, ballooning of the left ventricle, and minimal elevation of cardiac enzymes align perfectly with this diagnosis. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Gebrochenes-Herz syndrome) About Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken-heart syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a non-ischemic condition primarily affecting post-menopausal women. It features temporary left ventricular dysfunction that resembles a heart attack but with minimal cardiac enzyme release and no significant obstructive coronary artery disease. The name "Takotsubo" is derived from Japanese, meaning octopus trap, reflecting the ballooning shape of the left ventricle during contraction. Pathophysiology Catecholamine Hypothesis: Elevated catecholamines (norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) indicate stress-induced sympathetic overdrive, leading to microvascular spasms and myocardial injury. Microvascular Dysfunction: Impaired function is suggested by abnormalities in coronary flow reserve and microvascular resistance. Inflammation: Imaging may show myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis, with conditions like myocarditis and autoimmune diseases potentially triggering TC. Estrogen Deficiency: Exaggerated vasoconstriction and increased sympathetic activity in post-menopausal women contribute to TC. Clinical features Takotsubo cardiomyopathy often mimics acute coronary syndrome.(MI) Common Triggers: Emotional Stress: Events like the unexpected death of a loved one, domestic abuse, or financial loss. Physical Stress: Serious medical diagnoses or natural disasters. Symptoms: Chest pain, dyspnea, and syncope. Some patients may have signs of heart failure, such as tachyarrhythmias or bradyarrhythmias. A late-peaking systolic murmur may be present due to LVOTO (Left Ventricular Outflow Tract Obstruction). About 10% of patients may develop cardiogenic shock. Hypertensive Heart Disease (Option A): Caused by chronic high blood pressure, leading to left ventricular hypertrophy. This patient's history does not indicate long-standing hypertension. Coronary Artery Disease (Option C): Involves plaque buildup in coronary arteries, causing reduced blood flow. The absence of obstructive disease on angiography and minimal enzyme release suggests this is unlikely. Pulmonary Embolism (Option D): Occurs when a blood clot blocks a pulmonary artery, leading to sudden shortness of breath and chest pain. History of long term immobilization/ DVT is present. The patient's findings indicate a cardiac issue, not a pulmonary one. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1966 Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common echocardiographic finding associated with rheumatic carditis?
questions.explanation: episodes and 84% of recurrent cases of rheumatic carditis. Echocardiographic Findings in Rheumatic Carditis: Category Findings Incidence/Notes Mitral Valve Involvement Mitral regurgitation 94% in first episodes, 84% in recurrences Ventricular dilatation 54% in first episodes, 74% in recurrences Restricted leaflet mobility 37% of recurrent cases Valvular Abnormalities Valvular thickening Thickened mitral valve leaflets Focal valvular nodules 25%, usually resolved over time Other Cardiac Changes Left ventricular function Normal despite mitral regurgitation Congestive heart failure (CHF) 17% of first episodes, 40% of recurrences Follow-Up Valvular regurgitation outcomes 69% unchanged, 22% decreased, 9% disappeared Left ventricular dimensions Decrease over time Aortic regurgitation (Option A) is less common in rheumatic carditis compared to mitral regurgitation. Left ventricular hypertrophy (Option C) : While left ventricular function may be abnormal due to MR (due to volume overload and left ventricular dilatation), hypertrophy is not the primary finding in rheumatic carditis. Pericardial effusion (Option D) may occur but is not as prevalent as mitral regurgitation in rheumatic carditis. Reference: www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0146280623004383#:~:text=The%20morphological%20find ings%20on%20echocardiography,prolapse%20of%20the%20aortic%20valve.

questions.question: A 12 y/o girl presents with a recent onset of involuntary, jerky movements in her hands and face, worsening with stress or purposeful tasks. Her mother recalls multiple untreated sore throats months ago. O/E, she has irregular, rapid, non-rhythmic hand movements, difficulty with facial control, and trouble sustaining muscle contraction. Her motor function is otherwise normal. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation: following untreated streptococcal pharyngitis. The first episode of SC usually occurs 6 to 8 weeks after a strep throat infection. However, SC can also happen up to six months after a child has a fever, or the strep throat infection disappears. Signs seen in Sydenham's chorea: Tongue fasciculations (" Bag of worms ") Motor impersistence, for example, the "Milkmaid sign" (grip strength fluctuates, as if hand milking a cow), Inability to sustain tongue protrusion (called Jack-in-the-box tongue or Serpentine tongue , as the tongue slides in and out of the mouth) Penicillin prophylaxis is the initial step to prevent further streptococcal infection and recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever, even if no active infection is present. Treatment for Sydenham’s Chorea: If it is mild and non- debilitating: Then it is usually self-limiting. No treatment is required. For moderate to severe conditions: Category Medications Purpose Initial Antibiotic Prophylaxis Benzathine penicillin G Prevent the recurrence of rheumatic fever Additional Treatment Neuroleptics : Pimozide, haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine (Option B ruled out) Control chorea symptoms Anticonvulsants : Valproate, carbamazepine (Option D ruled out) Off-label use for symptom management Immunomodulatory Therapy Corticosteroids, Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), Plasma exchange (Option C ruled out) For severe/persistent symptoms Monitoring Gradual tapering after 1 month of symptom-free Reduce side effects Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5459984/#:~:text=Proposed%20treatments%20of%20chorea%20in, not%20covered%20in%20this%20review.

questions.question: A 25 y/o woman presents with h/o exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and episodes of syncope. She recalls experiencing multiple episodes of sore throat as a child, followed by joint pains, for which she received no definitive treatment. On auscultation, there is a diastolic murmur at the apex and a loud S1. She has heart rate of 75-80 bpm. An echocardiogram reveals significant mitral stenosis with left atrial enlargement. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

options.C: ACE Inhibitors and rate control drugs

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mitral balloon valvuloplasty Explanation: The patient has rheumatic mitral stenosis secondary to untreated rheumatic fever in childhood, leading to significant narrowing of the mitral valve and left atrial enlargement. Mitral balloon valvuloplasty is the treatment of choice for symptomatic patients with mitral stenosis who do not have significant mitral regurgitation or left atrial thrombus. It is a minimally invasive procedure that can significantly improve valve function and relieve symptoms. Management Strategies for RHD Complications: Condition Medical Management Interventional/Surgical Options Mitral Stenosis Anticoagulation to prevent embolism. Rate control (e.g., digoxin, beta-blockers, calcium antagonists) in AF. (Option C ruled out) Diuretics for pulmonary congestion. Balloon valvuloplasty. Mitral valvotomy. Mitral valve replacement. Mitral Regurgitation Diuretics and vasodilators for symptom relief. Digoxin and anticoagulants in AF. ACE inhibitors/ARBs for hypertension. (Option C ruled out) Mitral valve repair (preferred). (Option B ruled out) Mitral valve replacement (if repair is not feasible). Aortic Stenosis Not applicable Aortic valve replacement (for severe stenosis with symptoms like angina, syncope, or heart failure). Aortic Regurgitation Not applicable Aortic valve replacement (indicated for symptomatic cases, sometimes combined with aortic root replacement or coronary bypass). Managing Heart Failure: Therapy Details Medical Therapy Medications to improve cardiac function, reduce fluid overload, and control blood pressure. Eg. Diuretics, ACE inhibitors and ARBs Device Therapy ICD (Implantable cardiac defibrillators) : For preventing sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias. CRT (Cardiac resynchronisation therapy) : For improving heart function in heart failure with conduction abnormalities (e.g., left bundle branch block). Preventing Recurrent Rheumatic Fever and Infective Endocarditis: Prevention Strategy Details Long-Term Antibiotic Prophylaxis Prevents recurrent attacks of rheumatic fever. Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Procedures May be necessary before dental or surgical procedures to reduce the risk of infective endocarditis. Immediate mitral valve replacement (Option D) : Valve replacement is considered when valvuloplasty is not feasible or if the stenosis is accompanied by significant regurgitation or other complications, but it is not the first step in this case. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 465, 467, 517, 519, 521, 524, 525

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and occasional palpitations. She denies chest pain or fainting. O/E, she has an irregular pulse, a loud S1, an opening snap, and a low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex. She recalls a childhood illness with fever and joint pain requiring hospitalization. No signs of recent infection are present. Which of the following investigations is NOT primarily used in diagnosing her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Blood cultures Explanation: This clinical scenario suggests Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD), likely due to valvular damage caused by a past episode of acute rheumatic fever. The hallmark auscultatory findings of a loud S1, opening snap, and diastolic rumble are classic for mitral stenosis , a common consequence of RHD. Blood cultures are primarily used in diagnosing infective endocarditis , not for diagnosing RHD itself. They help identify pathogens when infection is suspected, particularly in patients with fever and valvular vegetation. Investigations for Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD): Category Details Diagnosis of RHD Blood Tests Leukocytosis, ESR, CRP Indicators of systemic illness. Raised ESR and CRP are common inflammatory markers. Throat Swab Culture Used to identify group A β -haemolytic streptococci . Cultures may also be taken from family members and contacts to confirm the source of infection. Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titres Elevated ASO levels (> 200 U in adults, > 300 U in children) or rising titres support the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. Normal ASO titres do not rule out the disease. Investigations Electrocardiogram (ECG) (Option B ruled out) Shows first-degree, and rarely, second-degree atrioventricular block. Pericarditis features. T-wave inversion. QRS voltage reduction. Chest X-ray (Option D ruled out) Identifies cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Echocardiography (Option A ruled out) Reveals cardiac dilatation. Detects valve abnormalities: Commonly mitral regurgitation with mitral annulus dilatation and anterior mitral leaflet prolapse. Shows aortic regurgitation. Identifies pericardial effusion. Excluding Differentials Other Valvular Diseases Infective endocarditis Blood cultures : Identify pathogens. Echocardiography : Detects vegetation on valves. Congenital heart defects Doppler Echocardiography : Identifies defects and abnormal blood flow patterns. Other Cardiac Conditions Cardiomyopathies Echocardiography/Cardiac MRI : Show structural/functional myocardial abnormalities to differentiate from RHD. Pericardial diseases Echocardiography : Detects pericardial effusion (pericarditis), and thickened pericardium (constrictive pericarditis). Non-Cardiac Conditions Pulmonary conditions Investigations : Chest X-ray, ECG, CT pulmonary angiogram (pulmonary embolism). Systemic illnesses Blood tests : Haemoglobin (anaemia), thyroid function, and kidney function to exclude other causes of cardiovascular symptoms. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 488, 517, 530, 536, 538, 542, 620

questions.question: Based on the 2015 Modified Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever, which of the following is NOT part of the major criteria for a low-risk population?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Polyarthralgia Explanation: Polyarthralgia is not part of the major criteria; it is a minor criterion for low-risk populations or a major criterion for high-risk populations. 2015 Modified Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever: Criteria Low-Risk Population High-Risk Population Major Criteria Carditis (clinical or subclinical) (Option A ruled out) Polyarthritis (Option B ruled out) Chorea (Option C ruled out) Erythema marginatum Subcutaneous nodules Carditis (clinical or subclinical) Monoarthritis or Polyarthritis Chorea Erythema marginatum Subcutaneous nodules Polyarthralgia (Option D) Minor Criteria Polyarthralgia (Option D) Hyperpyrexia ( ≥ 38.5ºC) ESR ≥ 60 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion) Monoarthralgia Hyperpyrexia ( ≥ 38.0ºC) ESR ≥ 30 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion) Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5911656/ Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 515

questions.question: Which statements describe the relationship between Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever?

options.A: It is an early manifestation of rheumatic fever
options.B: It occurs in all patients with rheumatic fever
options.C: It is associated with emotional lability
options.D: It has no connection to previous infections

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) It is associated with emotional lability Explanation: Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless movements, and significant emotional instability , often presenting as mood swings and obsessive-compulsive traits. It is more common in females. These features highlight its distinctive neurological profile as a complication of rheumatic fever. Other prominent manifestations of ARF: 1. Arthritis Prevalence and Onset : Occurs in approximately 75% of ARF patients. Presents acutely and also as migratory arthritis. Joint Involvement : Affects large joints asymmetrically, commonly the knees, ankles, elbows, and wrists. Each joint can be affected for 1 day to 4 weeks. Treatment : Rapidly improves with salicylates (aspirin) and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). 2. Skin Manifestations : Erythema Marginatum : Red macules with a red border, typically on the trunk and proximal limbs. Less than 5% prevalence Subcutaneous Nodules : Firm, painless nodules located over bony prominences, appearing more than 3 weeks after other symptoms. Less than 5% prevalence. It is an early manifestation of rheumatic fever (Option A): Sydenham's chorea typically arises as a delayed complication of acute rheumatic fever, emerging at least three months after the initial episode, rather than being an early symptom. It occurs in all patients with rheumatic fever (Option B): This condition does not affect every individual with rheumatic fever, rather, it affects approximately one-third of the cases. It has no connection to previous infections (Option D): Sydenham's chorea is directly related to previous streptococcal infections, as it is a complication that arises following acute rheumatic fever, which itself is triggered by such infections. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2767, 2768 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 516

questions.question: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a new onset heart murmur. On auscultation, a soft mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve inflammation. Which of the following murmurs is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: leaflets (valvulitis) in acute rheumatic fever (ARF). The inflammation causes nodular thickening of the valve. Murmur occurs due to increase blood flow across thickened leaflets of mitral valve. This is specifically associated with ARF and reflects early mitral valve involvement, which is common in rheumatic carditis. It differs from other murmurs because it is related to inflammation, not structural narrowing or regurgitation. Mitral stenosis murmur (Option A): Mitral stenosis typically results from long-term damage to the mitral valve, leading to the narrowing of the valve orifice. This condition is usually seen in chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD), not during the acute phase of rheumatic fever. On auscultation, Pan-diastolic murmur will be heard at apex. Aortic regurgitation murmur (Option B): Aortic regurgitation can occur in rheumatic fever, especially when the aortic valve is involved. However, it produces a distinct high-pitched early diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border. Pericardial friction rub (Option D): A pericardial friction rub occurs with pericarditis, which creates a leathery or scratchy sound distinct from murmurs caused by valvular inflammation. While pericarditis can occur in ARF, the friction rub is not related to the soft mid-diastolic murmur. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 280, 283, 2767 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 515, 516, 517

questions.question: Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) in the Indian population?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Polyarthritis Explanation: Polyarthritis is the most common symptom in ARF , seen in 60-75% of cases. In India, polyarthritis remains a prominent early manifestation of ARF. India has a high incidence of rheumatic heart disease, ranging from 13 to 150 cases per 100,000 population annually. (D 515) The course of Acute Rheumatic Fever Latent Period Common Early Features Late Features After upper respiratory tract infection/ pharyngitis with GABHS, ARF symptoms typically develop after a latent period of 3 weeks (range: 1–5 weeks). A sore throat can occur. Chorea and indolent carditis can manifest up to 6 months later following a prolonged latent period. Polyarthritis : Seen in 60-75% of ARF cases, often affecting large joints (knees, ankles, elbows). Migratory inflammation is a key feature. Carditis : Occurs in 50-75% of cases, frequently leading to mitral valve damage (regurgitation initially). Aortic valve involvement is also common.. Valvular damage can progress from regurgitation to stenosis over time, leading to heart failure in the long term. Recurrent ARF episodes increase the risk of chronic heart valve disease (rheumatic heart disease). Chorea: Varies by population, from less than 2% to 30%. Predominantly affects females and often coexists with carditis. Skin Manifestations : Erythema marginatum (rare, less than 5% of cases) and subcutaneous nodules (also less than 5%). (Options B and C ruled out) Pulmonary Hypertension (Option D): It is not a direct manifestation of ARF but can occur as a late complication due to left-sided valvular disease, particularly mitral valve involvement leading to pulmonary pressure increase. This complication is seen after years of progressive heart valve damage and is not a frequent presenting feature.

questions.question: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat. Examination reveals a heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Laboratory tests show elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

options.A: Direct invasion of heart valves by Streptococcus bacteria
options.B: Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue
options.C: Autoimmune destruction of heart valves due to viral infection
options.D: Genetic mutations in heart muscle proteins

questions.explanation: and heart tissue Correct answer: B) Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue Explanation: The clinical features point to Acute Rheumatic Fever(ARF). ARF results from antibodies reacting to group A Streptococcus antigens, which mimic heart tissue. Pathogenesis of Acute Rheumatic Fever: Immune Response: ARF is an autoimmune condition triggered by group A I hemolytic Streptococcus (GABHS) infection, leading the immune system to attack the body’s tissues. Molecular Mimicry : The immune system mistakes body tissues for GAS antigens, particularly due to similarities between the Streptococcus M protein and N-acetylglucosamine with human proteins. Heart Valve Damage: Cross-reactive antibodies bind to heart valve endothelial cells, activating VCAM-11, which attracts lymphocytes. This process leads to heart valve damage and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). T-cell Involvement: Damaged heart tissue releases peptides that activate cross-reactive T-cells, further amplifying tissue damage through epitope spreading. Susceptibility Factors: Genetic predispositions (e.g., HLA alleles) and specific Streptococcus strains influence the risk of developing ARF. HLA-DR7 and HLA-DR4 are associated with susceptibility to ARF. Direct invasion of heart valves by Streptococcus bacteria (Option A): ARF is not caused by direct bacterial invasion but by an autoimmune response. Autoimmune destruction of heart valves due to viral infection (Option C): RF is associated with bacterial, not viral, infections. Genetic mutations in heart muscle proteins (Option D): ARF involves immune responses, not genetic mutations affecting heart proteins. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2767

questions.question: A 16 y/o boy with a history of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) without carditis presents for follow-up. He has been on benzathine penicillin G for four years. Based on the AHA guidelines, what is the recommended duration for continuing secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

options.B: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 25
options.D: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21 Explanation: Secondary Prevention in Acute Rheumatic Fever Preferred Antibiotic Benzathine penicillin G is recommended as the first choice. Dosage is: 1.2 million units for individuals >27 kg. 600,000 units for individuals ≤ 27 kg. Typically administered every 4 weeks, may increase to every 2–3 weeks for adherence issues. Alternative Antibiotics Oral Erythromycin (250 mg twice daily) is recommended for patients allergic to penicillin. Oral penicillin V (250 mg twice daily) can be used but is less effective. Duration of Prophylaxis Determined by the presence and severity of carditis, age, and time since the last ARF episode No Carditis (Option B) 5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer. Carditis without Valvular Disease 10 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer. Persistent Valvular Disease 10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer. Lifelong prophylaxis may be needed in severe cases. Continue prophylaxis for 1 more year (Option A): The recommended duration is based on the time since the last attack and the patient’s age, not a fixed additional year. Continue prophylaxis until the age of 25 (Option B): AHA guidelines specify prophylaxis until the age of 21 or for five years, whichever is longer, in the absence of carditis. Discontinue prophylaxis immediately (Option C): Discontinuation before the age of 21 is not advised in the absence of carditis. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2770

questions.question: An interventional cardiologist is planning to implant an ICD in several patients. Which of the following patients is NOT an indication for ICD implantation according to the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Rhythm Society guidelines?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome Explanation: While Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can lead to arrhythmias, it is typically amenable to catheter ablation, making ICD implantation unnecessary in the absence of other risk factors. Indications for ICD Implantation Class I Indications Survivors of cardiac arrest from unstable sustained ventricular tachycardias (VT) Structural heart disease with spontaneous sustained VT. Unexplained syncope with significant sustained VT. Ischemic cardiomyopathy: LVEF <35%, >40 days post-MI, NYHA class II or III. Patients with LV dysfunction d/t a prior MI. Class IIa Indications Unexplained syncope with non-ischemic DCM and significant LV dysfunction. Sustained VT with normal ventricular function. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with risk factors for sudden cardiac death. (Option C ruled out) Prevention of sudden cardiac death in those with risk factors. Long QT syndrome with syncope or VT. (Option D ruled out) Patients awaiting transplantation. Brugada syndrome with syncope or documented VT. Catecholaminergic polymorphic VT with syncope on beta-blockers. Cardiac sarcoidosis, Chagas disease, giant cell myocarditis. (Option A ruled out) Class IIb Indications Non-ischemic heart disease with LVEF 35%, NYHA class I. Long QT syndrome with risk factors for sudden cardiac death. Sudden cardiac death with advanced structural heart disease and no cause. Familial cardiomyopathy associated with sudden death. LV noncompaction. Reference: Implantable Defibrillator - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1878-1880

questions.question: A 55 y/o male presents to the ED with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. His ECG is given below. Based on this information, which of the following changes is most likely present in this ECG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Coved ST elevation. Explanation: Coved ST elevation is often associated with acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and Type 1 Brugada syndrome. Given the patient's severe chest pain and presentation, this is the most likely change on the ECG. Type 1 Brugada pattern electrocardiogram induced by hypokalemia. Journal of Family Medicine and Primary Care. 5. 709-711. 10.4103/2249-4863.197295. " data-hash="8832" data-license="CC BY-NC-SA 4.0" data-source="https://www.res earchgate.net/figure/Coved-ST-segment-elevations-with-T-wave-inversions-in-leads-V1-and-V2-Figure-2_fig1_3 12030817" data-tags="April2025" height="340" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rbeNuKORXVdVh2tyYNd41744307041.png" width="629" /> Wide QRS complex (Option A): A normal QRS duration is less than 0.12 seconds (120 milliseconds), so a wide QRS is defined as being 0.12 seconds or longer. This is usually present in sodium channel blockade, hyperkalemia, hyper- or hypo-magnesemia, supraventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, etc. These features are not seen in this given ECG. Saddleback ST elevation (Option B) is associated with early repolarization or pericarditis or Type 2 Brugada syndrome. This change is not observed in the given ECG. Tall T waves (Option D): Tall T waves can indicate the hyperacute phase of myocardial infarction, prinzmetal angina, hyperkalemia, left ventricular hypertrophy, LBBB, acute pericarditis, etc. Tall T waves are not present in this ECG.

questions.question: A 35 y/o male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac deaths at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

options.A: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications
options.B: Perform a drug challenge test with procainamide
options.C: Refer for genetic testing for SCN5A mutations

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Implant an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator. Explanation: Brugada syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of characteristic ECG findings, including coved ST elevations greater than 2 mm in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) and often accompanied by a right bundle branch block. Clinically, patients may present with a range of symptoms from being asymptomatic to experiencing syncope or sudden cardiac death, particularly during sleep, with palpitations and dizziness also reported. Given the patient’s symptoms and ECG findings, an ICD is essential for immediate protection. Brugada Syndrome About A rare,

questions.question: A 68 y/o postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnea after a recent stressful event. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation and cardiac biomarkers are mildly elevated. After a thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with a condition resembling acute coronary syndrome. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.D: Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin. Explanation: The patient's symptoms, ST-segment elevation on ECG, and mild troponin elevation suggest Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, especially given her postmenopausal status and recent stress. The initial management focuses on ruling out obstructive coronary disease through coronary angiography while addressing acute symptoms. Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Investigations ECG Changes: Similar to pericarditis stages, with ST-segment elevation, T-wave inversions, and eventual normalization. Cardiac Biomarkers: Mild elevation of troponins (median initial troponin: 7.7 times normal) and elevated BNP or N-terminal pro-BNP levels. Echocardiography: Systolic apical ballooning of LV with mid-apical depression. Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance (CMR): Helps diagnose stress cardiomyopathy, showing myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis. Treatment Risk Factors for Adverse Outcomes: Physical triggers, neurologic/psychiatric conditions, high initial troponin, low ejection fraction, male gender. Initial Treatment: Aspirin, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, lipid-lowering agents, and coronary angiography. Stable Patients: Cardioselective beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for 3-6 months. Serial imaging to monitor wall motion and ejection fraction. Anticoagulation: Reserved for patients with ventricular thrombus (5% occurrence). (Option A ruled out) Unstable Patients: Inotropes for cardiogenic shock without left ventricular outflow obstruction. (Option C ruled out) Mechanical support (intra-aortic balloon pump or left ventricular assist devices) may be needed. If Outflow Obstruction Present: Avoid inotropes; phenylephrine is the preferred pressor, often combined with beta-blockers.
